src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/06/12/multimedia/author-ivan-penn/author-ivan-penn-thumbLarge.png" class="css-dc6zx6 ey68jwv2"/></a><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/karen-weise" class="css-uwwqev"><img alt="Karen Weise" title="Karen Weise" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2019/04/11/multimedia/author-karen-weise/author-karen-weise-thumbLarge-v2.png" class="css-dc6zx6 ey68jwv2"/></a></div><div class="css-233int epjyd6m1"><p class="css-4anu6l e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/ivan-penn" class="css-ojhyzr e1jsehar0" itemProp="name">Ivan Penn</a> and <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/karen-weise" class="last-byline css-ojhyzr e1jsehar0" itemProp="name">Karen Weise</a></p><div class="css-k9i8mi epjyd6m0"><div id="enhanced-byline" class="css-8atqhb"><p class="css-1hyokyd e1wtpvyy0">Ivan Penn reported from Anaheim, Calif.; Columbus, Ohio; and Los Angeles. Karen Weise reported from Seattle.</p></div></div></div></div><ul class="css-1cgskve epjyd6m4"><li class="css-ccw2r3 epjyd6m3"><time dateTime="2025-08-14T05:00:12-04:00" class="css-1gu861y e16638kd2"><span class="css-1sbuyqj e16638kd3">Aug. 14, 2025</span></time></li></ul></div></div></div><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-ar1ez3"><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-0"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">The annual meeting of state utility regulators is typically a humdrum affair of dry speeches and panel discussions. But in November, the scene at the Marriott in Anaheim, Calif., had a bit more flash.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">The conference’s top sponsors included the nation’s biggest tech companies — Amazon, Microsoft and Google. Their executives sat on panels, and the companies’ branding was plastered on product booths and at networking events. Even the lanyards around attendees’ necks were stamped with Google’s colorful logo.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Just a few years ago, tech companies were minor players in energy, making investments in solar and wind farms to rein in their growing carbon footprints and placate customers concerned about climate change. But now, they are changing the face of the U.S. power industry and blurring the line between energy consumer and energy producer. They have morphed into some of energy’s most dominant players.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">They have set up subsidiaries that invest in power generation and sell electricity. Much of the energy they produce is bought by utilities and then delivered to homes and businesses, including the tech companies themselves. Their operations and investments dwarf those of many traditional utilities.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-1"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-1"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">But the tech industry’s all-out artificial intelligence push is fueling soaring demand for electricity to run data centers that dot the landscape in Virginia, Ohio and other states. Large, rectangular buildings packed with servers consumed more than 4 percent of the nation’s electricity in 2023, and government <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.energy.gov/articles/doe-releases-new-report-evaluating-increase-electricity-demand-data-centers#:~:text=The%20report%20finds%20that%20data,total%20U.S.%20electricity%20by%202028." title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">analysts estimate</a> that will increase to as much as 12 percent in just three years. That’s partly because computers training and running A.I. systems <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2025/03/16/technology/ai-data-centers.html" title="">consume far more energy</a> than machines that stream Netflix or TikTok.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Electricity is essential to their success. Andy Jassy, Amazon’s chief executive, recently <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/07/31/business/amazon-earnings-second-quarter.html" title="">told</a> investors that the company could have had higher sales if it had more data centers. “The single biggest constraint,” he said, “is power.”</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">The rush to build power plants and transmission lines comes as big tech companies are richer than ever because of their pivot to A.I.; after announcing <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/07/30/technology/microsoft-earnings-ai-data-centers.html" title="">blowout financial results</a> in late July, Microsoft became the second public company to surpass $4 trillion in value.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Even as some corporate customers have been <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/08/13/business/ai-business-payoff-lags.html" title="">underwhelmed by A.I.’s usefulness</a> so far, tech companies plan to invest hundreds of billions of dollars on it.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">At the same time, the boom threatens to drive up power bills for residents and small businesses. Nationally, the average electricity rate for residents has risen more than 30 percent since 2020, after years of relatively modest increases. Much of that increase has been driven by utilities’ catching up on deferred maintenance and hardening grids for extreme weather.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-3"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-2"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">In the coming years, A.I. could turbocharge those increases.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">It is difficult to predict what that will mean for consumers’ power bills. But recent reports expect data centers will require expensive upgrades to the electric grid, a cost that will be shared with residents and smaller businesses through higher rates unless state regulators and lawmakers force tech companies to cover those expenses.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">A June <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.cmu.edu/work-that-matters/energy-innovation/data-center-growth-could-increase-electricity-bills" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">analysis</a>, from Carnegie Mellon University and North Carolina State University, found that electricity bills are on track to rise an average of 8 percent nationwide by 2030 and as much as 25 percent in places like Virginia because of data centers.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">In some places, it is happening already. Starting in June, the electricity bill for a typical household in Ohio increased at least $15 a month because of data centers, according to data from a major local utility and an independent monitor of the electric grid that stretches across 13 states and the District of Columbia.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Tech companies insist they are not trying to fob energy costs onto residents and small businesses, saying they are willing to pay for the power they use and for much of the equipment needed to make it available.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">“We don’t want to see other customers bearing the cost of us trying to grow,” said Bobby Hollis, who leads Microsoft’s energy procurement.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-5"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-3"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">But even with their expressed good will, getting the companies to make consumers whole will not be easy because determining how much large users like data centers should pay is not straightforward.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">The business of keeping America’s lights on is mostly about two things: supplying reliable electricity and figuring out what to charge to deliver it. In recent years, big tech companies have inserted themselves into debates over both. They lobby lawmakers and regulators, and they are pitching their own pricing schemes to challenge those of utilities — something that would have been unthinkable a few years ago.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">That has led to growing tensions.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">The utilities pay for grid projects over decades, typically by raising prices for everyone connected to the grid. But suddenly, technology companies want to build so many data centers that utilities are being asked to spend a lot more money a lot faster. Lawmakers, regulators and consumer groups fear that households and smaller companies could be stuck footing these mounting bills.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">For utilities, working with technology companies can be difficult but also lucrative.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">States allow utilities to charge customers enough to recoup their costs and make money for shareholders based on how much they invest. New data centers require utilities to spend billions of dollars on power lines and plants, which should lead to bigger profits for the utilities over time.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">“My No. 1 priority in all of this is to keep the lights on,” said Calvin Butler, the chief executive of Exelon, a large utility company, and the chairman of Edison Electric Institute, an industry association. “I think the tech companies’ being engaged in our industry makes this a very exciting time. Just pay your fair share of the grid.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-7"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-4"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Ultimately, the technology companies may have an upper hand. In many states bursting with data centers, utilities cannot own power plants because of policies intended to encourage competition. But the tech giants do not have the same restrictions, and many have invested in power plants and secured control of electricity produced by others, making them both big users and suppliers of power.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">The tech companies use the electricity produced at these facilities to help power their data centers or sell it to retail utilities on the wholesale market — a small but growing source of revenue. Over the past five years, electricity sales from tech companies’ energy subsidiaries totaled $2.2 billion, with much<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>of that generated since 2022.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="InteractiveBlock-9"><section data-testid="inline-interactive" id="datawrapper_YFz1h" data-id="100000010047284" data-uri="nyt://embeddedinteractive/6de69b09-a16f-5d1b-8bda-8fa567c40870" data-source-id="100000010047284" class="interactive-content interactive-size-scoop css-174j8de"><header id="interactive-header" class="css-obecq5 interactive-header"><h2 id="interactive-headline" class="css-4hk76s interactive-headline">Tech Companies’ Electricity Sales Have Surged</h2><p data-testid="leadin" id="interactive-leadin" class="css-1qa9noj interactive-leadin">Subsidiaries of major tech companies such as Amazon and Google have sold more than $2.7 billion on the wholesale electricity market in the past decade.</p></header><div class="css-17ih8de interactive-body" data-sourceid="100000010047284" id="embed-id-100000010047284">

<iframe src="https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/YFz1h/5/?plain=1" width="100%" height="400" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true"></iframe></div><footer id="interactive-footer" class="css-nt2azn interactive-footer"><p data-testid="source" id="interactive-source" class="css-cudxsp interactive-source">Source: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission</p><p data-testid="credit" id="interactive-credit" class="css-cudxsp interactive-credit">Jeremy Singer-Vine</p></footer></section></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-5"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">“Unless people lean on the public utilities commissions, the ratepayers will take it on the chin,” said Mark Cooper, an economic analyst at the Institute for Energy and the Environment at the Vermont Law and Graduate School.</p><h2 class="css-1njxe4c eoo0vm40" id="link-3e2f57b2">‘Extremely New Territory’</h2><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">In the debate over who will foot the bill, the industry’s eyes have been fixed on Ohio.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">On a snowy day in December, a first-of-its-kind showdown played out in a small hearing room in Columbus. Lawyers for Amazon, Google, Microsoft and other technology companies faced off against representatives of an electric utility.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-11"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-6"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">The tech companies had plans for dozens of new data centers, so much that the local utility, American Electric Power, projected it would need six times the electricity central Ohio produced.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">The utility had spent months meeting with the state’s consumer representative, tech companies and related industries, and the staff of the regulator, the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, to hammer out a deal.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-13"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-large css-hxpw2c e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="kyt-mdd4r">Image</span><picture><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 3dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 288dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/08/15/multimedia/00energy-tech02-mlpk/00energy-tech02-mlpk-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale&width=1800"/><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 2dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 192dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/08/15/multimedia/00energy-tech02-mlpk/00energy-tech02-mlpk-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale&width=1200"/><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 1dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 96dpi)" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/08/15/multimedia/00energy-tech02-mlpk/00energy-tech02-mlpk-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale&width=600"/><img alt="A hearing room with three seats raised and behind a wooden structure. The wall has the “Public Utilities Commission of Ohio” written on it in large letters with a logo to the left. There is an American flag to the left and an Ohio flag to the right." class="css-r3fift" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/08/15/multimedia/00energy-tech02-mlpk/00energy-tech02-mlpk-articleLarge-v2.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/08/15/multimedia/00energy-tech02-mlpk/00energy-tech02-mlpk-articleLarge-v2.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 600w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/08/15/multimedia/00energy-tech02-mlpk/00energy-tech02-mlpk-jumbo-v2.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 1024w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2025/08/15/multimedia/00energy-tech02-mlpk/00energy-tech02-mlpk-superJumbo-v2.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 2048w" sizes="((min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 1004px)) 84vw, (min-width: 1005px) 80vw, 100vw" uri="nyt://image/0ef2e6c7-76af-59cc-9f71-565a2ae27b17" decoding="async" width="600" height="397"/></picture></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-1g9ic6e ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">American Electric Power met with Ohio’s Public Utilities Commission to write a proposal that would create a new rate class for data centers and miners of cryptocurrencies.</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="kyt-mdd4r">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Brian Kaiser for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-7"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">But in October, before the negotiations were done, the tech companies gave the utility a few days’ notice that they were submitting their own proposal. Industry experts said they had never seen that kind of front-running before. Under the companies’ plan, they would pay less upfront than the utility had wanted.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Days later, the Ohio utility, the consumer representative and the regulator’s staff countered with a plan that would create a class of customer for data centers and would require them to pay more. This category would be in addition to the four main types of electricity customers — homes, businesses, factories and public rail systems — that pay different rates in Ohio and other states.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-15"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-8"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">The hearing in Columbus, before an administrative law judge, was about power in the literal sense — the electrons that keep the lights on and fuel modern technology — and power in the political sense.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">American Electric Power, which has 5.6 million customers in 11 states, warned the judge that if the state did not adopt its proposal, residents and smaller businesses would bear much of the costs for tech companies’ power demands.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Despite tech companies’ professed desire not to burden others, they often push regulators to impose some of the upgrade costs on everybody. They contend that data centers bring jobs to the area, and that grid upgrades will ultimately help local businesses and residents.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">At one point, a lawyer representing Amazon sought to get an executive from the Ohio utility to admit that he had once welcomed data centers to the state.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">“You said something to the effect of ‘Data centers are great for the economy,’” David Proaño, a partner at the law firm BakerHostetler, prodded. “Do you remember saying something like that?”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-17"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-9"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">The executive, Kamran Ali, deadpanned that he had “said a lot of things.” Mr. Ali testified that he worried about how the voracious power demands would tax the electric grid and hurt other consumers.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Scores of residential and business customers raised similar concerns in comments to Ohio regulators.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">“To even consider foisting more fees on Ohio’s private citizens is a travesty,” Benjamin Yoder, who lives in Blacklick, east of Columbus, <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://dis.puc.state.oh.us/ViewImage.aspx?CMID=A1001001A25A03A73020A02558" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">wrote</a> in a comment for a public hearing in January.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">An anonymous customer from Upper Sandusky <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://dis.puc.state.oh.us/ViewImage.aspx?CMID=A1001001A25A02C00001G02528" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">wrote</a>: “Our wallets cannot be strained anymore. Make them pay their own bills like we do!”</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">The utility in Ohio has already committed to supplying electricity for 30 data centers in the region by 2030, reaching power consumption levels in the Columbus area as high as Manhattan’s. But the tech industry is making additional requests to power 90 more data centers, which could make consumption comparable to the entire state of New York during a peak summer day.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-19"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-10"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">“We’re used to a couple megawatts added to our system,” Marc Reitter, president and chief operating officer at the utility, said in an interview. “Massive amounts of power is extremely new territory.”</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">The utility’s proposal for a new category of customer will require data centers to make years of payments for the energy they need — something other customers are not required to do.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">It wanted data centers and cryptocurrency miners to pay at least 85 percent of the electricity they request, even if they did not use it.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-21"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-large css-hxpw2c e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="kyt-mdd4r">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-1g9ic6e ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Transmission towers installed near the sites of several data centers and an Intel chip manufacturing plant in Johnstown, Ohio.</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="kyt-mdd4r">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Brian Kaiser for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-11"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">But Amazon, Google, Meta, Microsoft and other tech companies said they should pay less than what the utility wanted. The settlement the companies filed had committed to 75 percent of the electricity they requested, depending on the length of the contract. That would leave other utility customers to shoulder more of the cost of new grid equipment.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-23"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-12"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">In addition, the tech industry wanted all large customers, including factories, to be treated the same. And it proposed a higher threshold for determining if data centers should be considered large users than in the utility-led proposal.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Kevin Miller, who was until recently a vice president at Amazon, said the Ohio utility’s plan could result in tech companies’ overpaying because data centers ramp up operations in phases. And data centers could be required to pay for power even if the utility failed to deliver all the energy it had committed to supplying, he said.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">“We just don’t think that it has the right kind of flexibility to really match the profile over time that the data center brings,” Mr. Miller said in an interview before he left Amazon in July.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Last month, after <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://dis.puc.state.oh.us/CaseRecord.aspx?CaseNo=24-0508-EL-ATA" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">spending months weighing the proposals</a>, the commission ruled 5 to 0 against the tech companies.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">“Today’s order represents a well-balanced package that safeguards non-data-center customers,” Jenifer French, the chair of the commission, <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://puco.ohio.gov/news/puco-orders-aep-ohio-to-create-data-center-specific-tariff" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">said</a> in a statement after the ruling.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-25"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-13"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Last Friday, the tech companies asked the commission to reconsider the case, calling the ruling “unlawful and unreasonable.”</p><h2 class="css-1njxe4c eoo0vm40" id="link-71217dc7">Another Risk: Growth Could Falter</h2><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">The Ohio ruling hinged on a big concern for utilities and lawmakers: that the tech companies may be asking for a lot more power than they will ultimately use. The worry is that executives could overestimate demand for A.I. or underestimate the energy efficiency of future computer chips. Residents and smaller businesses would then be stuck covering much of the cost because utilities largely recoup the cost of improvements over time as customers use power rather than through upfront payments.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">These are not idle fears. Tech companies have announced plans for data centers that are never built or delayed for years.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">The utility’s executives said their proposal sought to protect all customers if tech companies abandoned or delayed projects. They pointed to <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.scc.virginia.gov/docketsearch#caseDocs/129370" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">a case</a> in Virginia, where regular customers had to cover initial costs of grid upgrades for a data center that started operating years later than planned.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">In that case, a developer of data centers, Unicorn Interests, told Dominion Energy, a large utility, in 2010 that it would build a data center next to the regional airport in Manassas, near Washington, that would need electricity by July 2013.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-27"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-14"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Virginia regulators approved Dominion’s $42 million plan to build a substation and a transmission line to serve the campus, which was run by an investment trust founded by the real estate developers Hossein Fateh and Lammot J. du Pont, a descendant of the du Pont dynasty. By late spring 2013, Dominion had procured most of the materials it needed for the project and done some site work, but Unicorn was behind schedule.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Ultimately, the data center did not <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.datacenterfrontier.com/cloud/article/11430643/cloudhq-unveils-massive-new-manassas-data-center" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">sign a customer</a> until summer 2017. During the four-year delay, ratepayers in and around Manassas paid millions of dollars for upgrades that were not being used. Because Unicorn was not drawing electricity from the new equipment, it paid Dominion nothing or very little in those years.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">In an interview, Mr. Fateh acknowledged the delays but said Unicorn had helped usher in a data center boom in the area.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">He also said he supported the utility industry’s efforts to have data centers make upfront payments for grid upgrades to weed out projects that might not be completed.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-29"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-15"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">“Most utilities really, really like our business because we are using a consistent amount of power, day or night,” he said. That means once they are up and running, data centers buy power all the time, unlike homes, which primarily use electricity in the morning and evening.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="ImageBlock-31"><div data-testid="imageblock-wrapper"><figure class="img-sz-large css-hxpw2c e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0" data-testid="photoviewer-children-figure"><span class="kyt-mdd4r">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption data-testid="photoviewer-children-caption" class="css-1g9ic6e ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Northern Virginia became home to many data centers because it has a nexus of critical internet cabling and government agencies.</span><span class="css-14fe1uy e1z0qqy90"><span class="kyt-mdd4r">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Nathan Howard for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-16"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">A spokesman for Dominion Energy, Aaron Ruby, said another data center project had replaced Unicorn and covered some of the costs, so “any impacts to residential customers would have been temporary and minimal, if anything at all.”</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Data centers are contractually required, Mr. Ruby said, to pay for the full cost of new distribution infrastructure — including substations and the poles and wires that connect the data center to the substation — within the first four years of their service.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">But that requirement does not apply to all upgrade costs. To serve large energy users, utilities also have to upgrade transmission lines that take electricity from power plants to the substation. The cost of upgrading those lines is generally borne by everyone.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Data centers have flocked to Northern Virginia because it is home to critical internet cabling and government agencies. The tech buildings now account for more than a quarter of the region’s energy use.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-33"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-17"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">A Virginia agency concluded in a report in December that data centers had generally been paying their fair share of grid upgrade expenses, but that costs to residents could rise $276 a year by 2030 because of data centers. That number could be substantially higher if construction plans for data centers are delayed, or if they are never built or use less electricity than planned.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">The report recommended that the state create a rate class for data centers — similar to the proposal that regulators approved in Ohio and other states are contemplating. At a <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.scc.virginia.gov/about-the-scc/newsreleases/release/commission-schedules-technical-conference-news/commission-schedules-technical-conference.html" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">hearing</a> in Richmond, Va., in December, the tech companies pushed back against that idea.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">“We do see an industry-specific rate class as discriminatory,” Brian George, a Google executive, said at the hearing. “Once we start going down that road, it does become a very slippery slope for how we can stop. If we assign it to one particular industry, how do we not assign it to another?”</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">But James Wilson, an energy economist who has consulted for consumer and environmental groups, noted that data centers accounted for almost all the electricity demand growth expected over the coming years in the Mid-Atlantic region.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">“Discrimination, yes; undue, not really,” he testified at the same hearing.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">The technology companies say they are open to compromises. In an interview, Amanda Peterson Corio, a Google executive responsible for data center energy, pointed to a deal with American Electric Power’s subsidiary in Indiana and consumer groups in that state, where tech companies agreed to pay some grid upgrade costs upfront to allay concerns about canceled or delayed projects.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-35"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-18"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">But under that deal, data centers are not put into a new rate class. “You start to isolate different classes and start to allocate who we’re going to give power to and who we’re not,” Ms. Corio said. “That goes against every construct of how our electricity system was designed, which is to be open access.”</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Tech companies say they plan to keep building data centers, but where those sites will be is uncertain. That puts utilities at risk of building more than their area needs.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">Microsoft, for example, announced plans in October to build three data center campuses that would require power from the Ohio utility. “The Columbus region’s skilled work force, strong infrastructure and strategic location make it ideal for this project,” the company said then.</p><p class="css-ac37hb evys1bk0">But six months later — before regulators ruled against the tech industry — Microsoft <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/04/30/technology/microsoft-earnings-ai-spending.html" title="">changed</a> its data center strategy and <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.dispatch.com/story/business/2025/04/07/microsoft-backs-out-of-plans-to-build-data-centers-in-licking-county/82973097007/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">said</a> it was putting the Ohio projects on ice. For the foreseeable future, those sites would remain farmland.</p><p class="css-798hid etfikam0">Jeremy Singer-Vine<!-- --> contributed reporting.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div></section><div class="bottom-of-article"><div class="css-1i6tsou"><div class="css-16kgnvc eqi4ubu0"><div><p>Ivan Penn is a reporter based in Los Angeles and covers the energy industry. His work has included reporting on clean energy, failures in the electric grid and the economics of utility services.</p></div></div><div class="css-16kgnvc eqi4ubu0"><div><p>Karen Weise writes about technology for The Times and is based in Seattle. Her coverage focuses on Amazon and Microsoft, two of the most powerful companies in America.</p></div></div></div><div class="css-lojhqv">A version of this article appears in print on <span class="css-1dmwf73"> </span>, Section <!-- -->B<!-- -->, Page <!-- -->1<!-- --> of the New York edition<!-- --> with the headline: <!-- -->As Tech Enters Energy Sector, A.I. As the electricity demands of the structures rapidly escalate, tech companies are becoming some of the most dominant players in energy.","uri":"nyt:\u002F\u002Fimage\u002Fe8bd9416-a997-5284-8444-06cbea37d73a"},"size":"MEDIUM"},"mobileHeadlineColor":"WHITE","summary":{"__typename":"SummaryBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Electricity rates for individuals and small businesses could rise sharply as Amazon, Google, Microsoft and other technology companies build data centers and expand into the energy business."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},"textPosition":{"__typename":"HeaderFullBleedTextPosition","desktop":"DESKTOP_CENTER_CENTER","mobile":"MOBILE_CENTER_CENTER"},"timestampBlock":{"__typename":"TimestampBlock","align":"LEFT","showUpdatedTimestamp":null,"timestamp":"2025-08-14T09:00:12.000Z"}},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The annual meeting of state utility regulators is typically a humdrum affair of dry speeches and panel discussions. But in November, the scene at the Marriott in Anaheim, Calif., had a bit more flash."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":0},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The conference’s top sponsors included the nation’s biggest tech companies — Amazon, Microsoft and Google. Their executives sat on panels, and the companies’ branding was plastered on product booths and at networking events. Even the lanyards around attendees’ necks were stamped with Google’s colorful logo."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":1},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Just a few years ago, tech companies were minor players in energy, making investments in solar and wind farms to rein in their growing carbon footprints and placate customers concerned about climate change. But now, they are changing the face of the U.S. power industry and blurring the line between energy consumer and energy producer. They have morphed into some of energy’s most dominant players."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":2},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"They have set up subsidiaries that invest in power generation and sell electricity. Much of the energy they produce is bought by utilities and then delivered to homes and businesses, including the tech companies themselves. Their operations and investments dwarf those of many traditional utilities."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":true,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":3},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"But the tech industry’s all-out artificial intelligence push is fueling soaring demand for electricity to run data centers that dot the landscape in Virginia, Ohio and other states. Large, rectangular buildings packed with servers consumed more than 4 percent of the nation’s electricity in 2023, and government "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.energy.gov\u002Farticles\u002Fdoe-releases-new-report-evaluating-increase-electricity-demand-data-centers#:~:text=The%20report%20finds%20that%20data,total%20U.S.%20electricity%20by%202028."}],"text":"analysts estimate"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":" that will increase to as much as 12 percent in just three years. That’s partly because computers training and running A.I. systems "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2025\u002F03\u002F16\u002Ftechnology\u002Fai-data-centers.html"}],"text":"consume far more energy"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":" than machines that stream Netflix or TikTok."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":4},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Electricity is essential to their success. Andy Jassy, Amazon’s chief executive, recently "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2025\u002F07\u002F31\u002Fbusiness\u002Famazon-earnings-second-quarter.html"}],"text":"told"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":" investors that the company could have had higher sales if it had more data centers. “The single biggest constraint,” he said, “is power.”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":5},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The rush to build power plants and transmission lines comes as big tech companies are richer than ever because of their pivot to A.I.; after announcing "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2025\u002F07\u002F30\u002Ftechnology\u002Fmicrosoft-earnings-ai-data-centers.html"}],"text":"blowout financial results"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":" in late July, Microsoft became the second public company to surpass $4 trillion in value."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":6},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Even as some corporate customers have been "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2025\u002F08\u002F13\u002Fbusiness\u002Fai-business-payoff-lags.html"}],"text":"underwhelmed by A.I.’s usefulness"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":" so far, tech companies plan to invest hundreds of billions of dollars on it."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":true,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":7},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"At the same time, the boom threatens to drive up power bills for residents and small businesses. Nationally, the average electricity rate for residents has risen more than 30 percent since 2020, after years of relatively modest increases. Much of that increase has been driven by utilities’ catching up on deferred maintenance and hardening grids for extreme weather."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":8},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"In the coming years, A.I. could turbocharge those increases."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"It is difficult to predict what that will mean for consumers’ power bills. But recent reports expect data centers will require expensive upgrades to the electric grid, a cost that will be shared with residents and smaller businesses through higher rates unless state regulators and lawmakers force tech companies to cover those expenses."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":9},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"A June "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cmu.edu\u002Fwork-that-matters\u002Fenergy-innovation\u002Fdata-center-growth-could-increase-electricity-bills"}],"text":"analysis"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":", from Carnegie Mellon University and North Carolina State University, found that electricity bills are on track to rise an average of 8 percent nationwide by 2030 and as much as 25 percent in places like Virginia because of data centers."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":10},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"In some places, it is happening already. Starting in June, the electricity bill for a typical household in Ohio increased at least $15 a month because of data centers, according to data from a major local utility and an independent monitor of the electric grid that stretches across 13 states and the District of Columbia."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":true,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":11},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Tech companies insist they are not trying to fob energy costs onto residents and small businesses, saying they are willing to pay for the power they use and for much of the equipment needed to make it available."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":12},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“We don’t want to see other customers bearing the cost of us trying to grow,” said Bobby Hollis, who leads Microsoft’s energy procurement."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":13},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"But even with their expressed good will, getting the companies to make consumers whole will not be easy because determining how much large users like data centers should pay is not straightforward."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":14},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The business of keeping America’s lights on is mostly about two things: supplying reliable electricity and figuring out what to charge to deliver it. In recent years, big tech companies have inserted themselves into debates over both. They lobby lawmakers and regulators, and they are pitching their own pricing schemes to challenge those of utilities — something that would have been unthinkable a few years ago."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":true,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":15},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"That has led to growing tensions."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The utilities pay for grid projects over decades, typically by raising prices for everyone connected to the grid. But suddenly, technology companies want to build so many data centers that utilities are being asked to spend a lot more money a lot faster. Lawmakers, regulators and consumer groups fear that households and smaller companies could be stuck footing these mounting bills."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":16},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"For utilities, working with technology companies can be difficult but also lucrative."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"States allow utilities to charge customers enough to recoup their costs and make money for shareholders based on how much they invest. New data centers require utilities to spend billions of dollars on power lines and plants, which should lead to bigger profits for the utilities over time."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":17},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“My No. 1 priority in all of this is to keep the lights on,” said Calvin Butler, the chief executive of Exelon, a large utility company, and the chairman of Edison Electric Institute, an industry association. “I think the tech companies’ being engaged in our industry makes this a very exciting time. Just pay your fair share of the grid.”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":18},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Ultimately, the technology companies may have an upper hand. In many states bursting with data centers, utilities cannot own power plants because of policies intended to encourage competition. But the tech giants do not have the same restrictions, and many have invested in power plants and secured control of electricity produced by others, making them both big users and suppliers of power."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":true,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":19},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The tech companies use the electricity produced at these facilities to help power their data centers or sell it to retail utilities on the wholesale market — a small but growing source of revenue. Over the past five years, electricity sales from tech companies’ energy subsidiaries totaled $2.2 billion, with much"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"BoldFormat","type":null}],"text":" "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"of that generated since 2022."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":true,"index":20},{"__typename":"InteractiveBlock","media":{"__typename":"EmbeddedInteractive","advertisingProperties":{"__typename":"CreativeWorkAdvertisingProperties","sensitivity":"SHOW_ADS"},"appName":"Datawrapper","bylines":[],"compatibility":"INLINE","credit":"Jeremy Graduate School."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":22},{"__typename":"Heading2Block","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"‘Extremely New Territory’"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"In the debate over who will foot the bill, the industry’s eyes have been fixed on Ohio."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"On a snowy day in December, a first-of-its-kind showdown played out in a small hearing room in Columbus. Lawyers for Amazon, Google, Microsoft and other technology companies faced off against representatives of an electric utility."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":true,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":23},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The tech companies had plans for dozens of new data centers, so much that the local utility, American Electric Power, projected it would need six times the electricity central Ohio produced."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":24},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The utility had spent months meeting with the state’s consumer representative, tech companies and related industries, and the staff of the regulator, the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, to hammer out a deal."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":true,"index":25},{"__typename":"ImageBlock","media":{"__typename":"Image","altText":"A hearing room with three seats raised and behind a wooden structure. gacyHtmlCaption":"American Electric Power met with Ohio’s Public Utilities Commission to write a proposal that would create a new rate class for data centers and miners of cryptocurrencies.","timesTags":[],"uri":"nyt:\u002F\u002Fimage\u002F0ef2e6c7-76af-59cc-9f71-565a2ae27b17","url":"\u002Fimagepages\u002F2025\u002F08\u002F14\u002Fmultimedia\u002F00energy-tech02-mlpk.html"},"size":"LARGE"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":true,"index":26},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"But in October, before the negotiations were done, the tech companies gave the utility a few days’ notice that they were submitting their own proposal. Industry experts said they had never seen that kind of front-running before. Under the companies’ plan, they would pay less upfront than the utility had wanted."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":true,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"bad":false,"index":27},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Days later, the Ohio utility, the consumer representative and the regulator’s staff countered with a plan that would create a class of customer for data centers and would require them to pay more. This category would be in addition to the four main types of electricity customers — homes, businesses, factories and public rail systems — that pay different rates in Ohio and other states."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":28},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The hearing in Columbus, before an administrative law judge, was about power in the literal sense — the electrons that keep the lights on and fuel modern technology — and power in the political sense."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":29},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"American Electric Power, which has 5.6 million customers in 11 states, warned the judge that if the state did not adopt its proposal, residents and smaller businesses would bear much of the costs for tech companies’ power demands."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":30},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Despite tech companies’ professed desire not to burden others, they often push regulators to impose some of the upgrade costs on everybody. They contend that data centers bring jobs to the area, and that grid upgrades will ultimately help local businesses and residents."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":true,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":31},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"At one point, a lawyer representing Amazon sought to get an executive from the Ohio utility to admit that he had once welcomed data centers to the state."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":32},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“You said something to the effect of ‘Data centers are great for the economy,’” David Proaño, a partner at the law firm BakerHostetler, prodded. “Do you remember saying something like that?”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":33},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The executive, Kamran Ali, deadpanned that he had “said a lot of things.” Mr. Ali testified that he worried about how the voracious power demands would tax the electric grid and hurt other consumers."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":34},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Scores of residential and business customers raised similar concerns in comments to Ohio regulators."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":true,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":35},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“To even consider foisting more fees on Ohio’s private citizens is a travesty,” Benjamin Yoder, who lives in Blacklick, east of Columbus, "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fdis.puc.state.oh.us\u002FViewImage.aspx?CMID=A1001001A25A03A73020A02558"}],"text":"wrote"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":" in a comment for a public hearing in January."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":36},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"An anonymous customer from Upper Sandusky "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fdis.puc.state.oh.us\u002FViewImage.aspx?CMID=A1001001A25A02C00001G02528"}],"text":"wrote"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":": “Our wallets cannot be strained anymore. Make them pay their own bills like we do!”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":37},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The utility in Ohio has already committed to supplying electricity for 30 data centers in the region by 2030, reaching power consumption levels in the Columbus area as high as Manhattan’s. But the tech industry is making additional requests to power 90 more data centers, which could make consumption comparable to the entire state of New York during a peak summer day."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":38},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“We’re used to a couple megawatts added to our system,” Marc Reitter, president and chief operating officer at the utility, said in an interview. “Massive amounts of power is extremely new territory.”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":true,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":39},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The utility’s proposal for a new category of customer will require data centers to make years of payments for the energy they need — something other customers are not required to do."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":40},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"It wanted data centers and cryptocurrency miners to pay at least 85 percent of the electricity they request, even if they did not use it."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":true,"index":41},{"__typename":"ImageBlock","media":{"__typename":"Image","altText":"Snow Amazon, Google, Meta, Microsoft and other tech companies said they should pay less than what the utility wanted. The settlement the companies filed had committed to 75 percent of the electricity they requested, depending on the length of the contract. That would leave other utility customers to shoulder more of the cost of new grid equipment."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":true,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":43},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"In addition, the tech industry wanted all large customers, including factories, to be treated the same. And it proposed a higher threshold for determining if data centers should be considered large users than in the utility-led proposal."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":44},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Kevin Miller, who was until recently a vice president at Amazon, said the Ohio utility’s plan could result in tech companies’ overpaying because data centers ramp up operations in phases. And data centers could be required to pay for power even if the utility failed to deliver all the energy it had committed to supplying, he said."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":45},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“We just don’t think that it has the right kind of flexibility to really match the profile over time that the data center brings,” Mr. Miller said in an interview before he left Amazon in July."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":46},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Last month, after "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fdis.puc.state.oh.us\u002FCaseRecord.aspx?CaseNo=24-0508-EL-ATA"}],"text":"spending months weighing the proposals"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":", the commission ruled 5 to 0 against the tech companies."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":true,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":47},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“Today’s order represents a well-balanced package that safeguards non-data-center customers,” Jenifer French, the chair of the commission, "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fpuco.ohio.gov\u002Fnews\u002Fpuco-orders-aep-ohio-to-create-data-center-specific-tariff"}],"text":"said"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":" in a statement after the ruling."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":48},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Last Friday, the tech companies asked the commission to reconsider the case, calling the ruling “unlawful and unreasonable.”"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":49},{"__typename":"Heading2Block","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Another Risk: Growth Could Falter"}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The Ohio ruling hinged on a big concern for utilities and lawmakers: that the tech companies may be asking for a lot more power than they will ultimately use. The worry is that executives could overestimate demand for A.I. or underestimate the energy efficiency of future computer chips. Residents and smaller businesses would then be stuck covering much of the cost because utilities largely recoup the cost of improvements over time as customers use power rather than through upfront payments."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":50},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"These are not idle fears. Tech companies have announced plans for data centers that are never built or delayed for years."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":51},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"The utility’s executives said their proposal sought to protect all customers if tech companies abandoned or delayed projects. They pointed to "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.scc.virginia.gov\u002Fdocketsearch#caseDocs\u002F129370"}],"text":"a case"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":" in Virginia, where regular customers had to cover initial costs of grid upgrades for a data center that started operating years later than planned."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":52},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"In that case, a developer of data centers, Unicorn Interests, told Dominion Energy, a large utility, in 2010 that it would build a data center next to the regional airport in Manassas, near Washington, that would need electricity by July 2013."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":53},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Virginia regulators approved Dominion’s $42 million plan to build a substation and a transmission line to serve the campus, which was run by an investment trust founded by the real estate developers Hossein Fateh and Lammot J. du Pont, a descendant of the du Pont dynasty. By late spring 2013, Dominion had procured most of the materials it needed for the project and done some site work, but Unicorn was behind schedule."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":54},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"Ultimately, the data center did not "},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","title":"","uri":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.datacenterfrontier.com\u002Fcloud\u002Farticle\u002F11430643\u002Fcloudhq-unveils-massive-new-manassas-data-center"}],"text":"sign a customer"},{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":" until summer 2017. During the four-year delay, ratepayers in and around Manassas paid millions of dollars for upgrades that were not being used. Because Unicorn was not drawing electricity from the new equipment, it paid Dominion nothing or very little in those years."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":55},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"In an interview, Mr. Fateh acknowledged the delays but said Unicorn had helped usher in a data center boom in the area."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":56},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"He also said he supported the utility industry’s efforts to have data centers make upfront payments for grid upgrades to weed out projects that might not be completed."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":true,"adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":false,"index":57},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","formats":[],"text":"“Most utilities really, really like our business because we are using a consistent amount of power, day or night,” he said. That means once they are up and running, data centers buy power all the time, unlike homes, which primarily use electricity in the morning and evening."}],"textAlign":"LEFT"},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktop":false,"adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsHybrid":false,"adsHybridHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"bad":true,"index":58},{"__typename":"ImageBlock","media":{"__typename":"Image","altText":"A
